column2: FAMILY DOCTORS
column3: FAMILY DOCTORS

column2: From 'Emma'
column3: From 'Emma'

column2: While they were thus comfortably occupied, Mr. Woodhouse was enjoying a full flow of happy regrets and tearful affection with his daughter.
column3: While they were thus comfortably occupied, mr Woodhouse was enjoying a full flow of happy regrets and tearful affection with his daughter.

column2: My poor, dear Isabella, said he, fondly taking her hand, and interrupting for a few moments her busy labors for some one of her five children, "how long it is, how terribly long since you were here!
column3: My poor, dear Isabella, said he, fondly taking her hand, and interrupting for a few moments her busy labors for some one of her five children, "how long it is, how terribly long since you were here!

column2: And how tired you must be after your journey!
column3: And how tired you must be after your journey!

column2: You must go to bed early, my dear,--and I recommend a little gruel to you before you go.
column3: You must go to bed early, my dear,--and I recommend a little gruel to you before you go.

column2: You and I will have a nice basin of gruel together.
column3: You and I will have a nice basin of gruel together.

column2: My dear Emma, suppose we all have a little gruel."
column3: My dear Emma, suppose we all have a little gruel."

column2: Emma could not suppose any such thing, knowing as she did that both the Mr. Knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article as herself, and two basins only were ordered.
column3: Emma could not suppose any such thing, knowing as she did that both the mr Knightleys were as unpersuadable on that article as herself, and two basins only were ordered.

column2: After a little more discourse in praise of gruel, with some wondering at its not being taken every evening by everybody, he proceeded to say, with an air of grave reflection:--
column3: After a little more discourse in praise of gruel, with some wondering at its not being taken every evening by everybody, he proceeded to say, with an air of grave reflection:--

column2: It was an awkward business, my dear, your spending the autumn at South End instead of coming here.	It was an awkward business, my dear, your spending the autumn at South End instead of coming here.
column3: true

column2: I never had much opinion of the sea air."
column3: I never had much opinion of the sea air."

column2: Mr. Wingfield most strenuously recommended it, sir, or we should not have gone.	mr Wingfield most strenuously recommended it, sir, or we should not have gone.
column3: true

column2: He recommended it for all the children, but particularly for the weakness in little Bella's throat,--both sea air and bathing."
column3: He recommended it for all the children, but particularly for the weakness in little Bella's throat,--both sea air and bathing."

column2: Ah, my dear, but Perry had many doubts about the sea doing her any good; and as to myself, I have been long perfectly convinced, though perhaps I never told you so before, that the sea is very rarely of use to anybody.	Ah, my dear, but Perry had many doubts about the sea doing her any good; and as to myself, I have been long perfectly convinced, though perhaps I never told you so before, that the sea is very rarely of use to anybody.
column3: false

column2: I am sure it almost killed me once."
column3: I am sure it almost killed me once."

column2: Come, come, cried Emma, feeling this to be an unsafe subject, "I must beg you not to talk of the sea.
column3: Come, come, cried Emma, feeling this to be an unsafe subject, "I must beg you not to talk of the sea.

column2: It makes me envious and miserable; I who have never seen it!
column3: It makes me envious and miserable; I who have never seen it!

column2: South End is prohibited, if you please.
column3: South End is prohibited, if you please.

column2: My dear Isabella, I have not heard you make one inquiry after Mr. Perry yet; and he never forgets you."
column3: My dear Isabella, I have not heard you make one inquiry after mr Perry yet; and he never forgets you."

column2: Oh, good Mr. Perry, how is he, sir?
column3: Oh, good mr Perry, how is he, sir?

column2: Why, pretty well; but not quite well.	Why, pretty well; but not quite well.
column3: true

column2: Poor Perry is bilious, and he has not time to take care of himself; he tells me he has not time to take care of himself--which is very sad--but he is always wanted all round the country.
column3: Poor Perry is bilious, and he has not time to take care of himself; he tells me he has not time to take care of himself-which is very sad-but he is always wanted all round the country.

column2: I suppose there is not a man in such practice anywhere.
column3: I suppose there is not a man in such practice anywhere.

column2: But then, there is not so clever a man anywhere."
column3: But then, there is not so clever a man anywhere."

column2: And Mrs. Perry and the children, how are they?	And mrs Perry and the children, how are they?
column3: false

column2: Do the children grow?
column3: Do the children grow?

column2: I have a great regard for Mr. Perry.
column3: I have a great regard for mr Perry.

column2: I hope he will be calling soon.
column3: I hope he will be calling soon.

column2: He will be so pleased to see my little ones."
column3: He will be so pleased to see my little ones."

column2: I hope he will be here to-morrow, for I have a question or two to ask him about myself of some consequence.	I hope he will be here to morrow, for I have a question or two to ask him about myself of some consequence.
column3: false

column2: And, my dear, whenever he comes, you had better let him look at little Bella's throat."
column3: And, my dear, whenever he comes, you had better let him look at little Bella's throat."

column2: Oh, my dear sir, her throat is so much better that I have hardly any uneasiness about it.	Oh, my dear sir, her throat is so much better that I have hardly any uneasiness about it.
column3: false

column2: Either bathing has been of the greatest service to her, or else it is to be attributed to an excellent embrocation of Mr. Wingfield's, which we have been applying at times ever since August."
column3: Either bathing has been of the greatest service to her, or else it is to be attributed to an excellent embrocation of mr Wingfield's, which we have been applying at times ever since August."

column2: It is not very likely, my dear, that bathing should have been of use to her; and if I had known you were wanting an embrocation, I would have spoken to--
column3: It is not very likely, my dear, that bathing should have been of use to her; and if I had known you were wanting an embrocation, I would have spoken to-

column2: You seem to me to have forgotten Mrs. and Miss Bates, said Emma: "I have not heard one inquiry after them."
column3: You seem to me to have forgotten mrs and Miss Bates, said Emma: "I have not heard one inquiry after them."

column2: Oh, the good Bateses--I am quite ashamed of myself; but you mention them in most of your letters.	Oh, the good Bateses-I am quite ashamed of myself; but you mention them in most of your letters.
column3: false

column2: I hope they are quite well.
column3: I hope they are quite well.

column2: Good old Mrs. Bates.
column3: Good old mrs Bates.

column2: I will call upon her to-morrow, and take my children.
column3: I will call upon her to morrow, and take my children.

column2: They are always so pleased to see my children.
column3: They are always so pleased to see my children.

column2: And that excellent Miss Bates!--such thorough worthy people!
column3: And that excellent Miss Bates!--such thorough worthy people!

column2: How are they, sir?"
column3: How are they, sir?"

column2: Why, pretty well, my dear, upon the whole.	Why, pretty well, my dear, upon the whole.
column3: true

column2: But poor Mrs. Bates had a bad cold about a month ago."
column3: But poor mrs Bates had a bad cold about a month ago."

column2: How sorry I am! but colds were never so prevalent as they have been this autumn.	How sorry I am! but colds were never so prevalent as they have been this autumn.
column3: true

column2: Mr. Wingfield told me that he had never known them more general or heavy, except when it has been quite an influenza."
column3: mr Wingfield told me that he had never known them more general or heavy, except when it has been quite an influenza."

column2: That has been a good deal the case, my dear, but not to the degree you mention.	That has been a good deal the case, my dear, but not to the degree you mention.
column3: true

column2: Perry says that colds have been very general, but not so heavy as he has very often known them in November.
column3: Perry says that colds have been very general, but not so heavy as he has very often known them in November.

column2: Perry does not call it altogether a sickly season."
column3: Perry does not call it altogether a sickly season."

column2: No, I do not know that Mr. Wingfield considers it _very_ sickly, except--
column3: No, I do not know that mr Wingfield considers it underscore very underscore sickly, except-

column2: Ah, my poor, dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always a sickly season.	Ah, my poor, dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always a sickly season.
column3: false

column2: Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be.
column3: Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be.

column2: It is a dreadful thing to have you forced to live there;--so far off!--and the air so bad!"
column3: It is a dreadful thing to have you forced to live there;--so far off!--and the air so bad!"

column2: No, indeed, _we_ are not at all in a bad air.	No, indeed, underscore we underscore are not at all in a bad air.
column3: false

column2: Our part of London is so very superior to most others.
column3: Our part of London is so very superior to most others.

column2: You must not confound us with London in general, my dear sir.
column3: You must not confound us with London in general, my dear sir.

column2: The neighborhood of Brunswick Square is very different from almost all the rest.
column3: The neighborhood of Brunswick Square is very different from almost all the rest.

column2: We are so very airy!
column3: We are so very airy!

column2: I should be unwilling, I own, to live in any other part of the town; there is hardly any other that I could be satisfied to have my children in: but _we_ are so remarkably airy!
column3: I should be unwilling, I own, to live in any other part of the town; there is hardly any other that I could be satisfied to have my children in: but underscore we underscore are so remarkably airy!

column2: Mr. Wingfield thinks the vicinity of Brunswick Square decidedly the most favorable as to air."
column3: mr Wingfield thinks the vicinity of Brunswick Square decidedly the most favorable as to air."

column2: Ah, my dear, it is not like Hartfield.	Ah, my dear, it is not like Hartfield.
column3: false

column2: You make the best of it--but after you have been a week at Hartfield, you are all of you different creatures; you do not look like the same.
column3: You make the best of it-but after you have been a week at Hartfield, you are all of you different creatures; you do not look like the same.

column2: Now, I cannot say that I think you are any of you looking well at present."
column3: Now, I cannot say that I think you are any of you looking well at present."

column2: I am sorry to hear you say so, sir; but I assure you, excepting those little nervous headaches and palpitations which I am never entirely free from anywhere, I am quite well myself; and if the children were rather pale before they went to bed, it was only because they were a little more tired than usual from their journey and the happiness of coming.	I am sorry to hear you say so, sir; but I assure you, excepting those little nervous headaches and palpitations which I am never entirely free from anywhere, I am quite well myself; and if the children were rather pale before they went to bed, it was only because they were a little more tired than usual from their journey and the happiness of coming.
column3: true

column2: I hope you will think better of their looks to-morrow; for I assure you Mr. Wingfield told me that he did not believe he had ever sent us off, altogether, in such good case.
column3: I hope you will think better of their looks to morrow; for I assure you mr Wingfield told me that he did not believe he had ever sent us off, altogether, in such good case.

column2: I trust at least that you do not think Mr. Knightley looking ill," turning her eyes with affectionate anxiety toward her husband.
column3: I trust at least that you do not think mr Knightley looking ill," turning her eyes with affectionate anxiety toward her husband.

column2: Middling, my dear; I cannot compliment you.	Middling, my dear; I cannot compliment you.
column3: true

column2: I think Mr. John Knightley very far from looking well."
column3: I think mr john Knightley very far from looking well."

column2: What is the matter, sir?	What is the matter, sir?
column3: true

column2: Did you speak to me?" cried Mr. John Knightley, hearing his own name.
column3: Did you speak to me?" cried mr john Knightley, hearing his own name.

column2: I am sorry to find, my love, that my father does not think you looking well; but I hope it is only from being a little fatigued.	I am sorry to find, my love, that my father does not think you looking well; but I hope it is only from being a little fatigued.
column3: true

column2: I could have wished, however, as you know, that you had seen Mr. Wingfield before you left home."
column3: I could have wished, however, as you know, that you had seen mr Wingfield before you left home."

column2: My dear Isabella, exclaimed he hastily, "pray do not concern yourself about my looks.
column3: My dear Isabella, exclaimed he hastily, "pray do not concern yourself about my looks.

column2: Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling yourself and the children, and let me look as I choose."
column3: Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling yourself and the children, and let me look as I choose."

column2: I did not thoroughly understand what you were telling your brother, cried Emma, "about your friend Mr. Graham's intending to have a bailiff from Scotland to look after his new estate.
column3: I did not thoroughly understand what you were telling your brother, cried Emma, "about your friend mr Graham's intending to have a bailiff from Scotland to look after his new estate.

column2: But will it answer?
column3: But will it answer?

column2: Will not the old prejudice be too strong?"
column3: Will not the old prejudice be too strong?"

column2: And she talked in this way so long and successfully that, when forced to give her attention again to her father and sister, she had nothing worse to hear than Isabella's kind inquiry after Jane Fairfax; and Jane Fairfax, though no great favorite with her in general, she was at that moment very happy to assist in praising.
column3: And she talked in this way so long and successfully that, when forced to give her attention again to her father and sister, she had nothing worse to hear than Isabella's kind inquiry after Jane Fairfax; and Jane Fairfax, though no great favorite with her in general, she was at that moment very happy to assist in praising.

column2: That sweet, amiable Jane Fairfax! said Mrs. John Knightley.
column3: That sweet, amiable Jane Fairfax! said mrs john Knightley.

column2: It is so long since I have seen her, except now and then for a moment accidentally in town.	It is so long since I have seen her, except now and then for a moment accidentally in town.
column3: true

column2: What happiness it must be to her good old grandmother and excellent aunt when she comes to visit them!
column3: What happiness it must be to her good old grandmother and excellent aunt when she comes to visit them!

column2: I always regret excessively, on dear Emma's account, that she cannot be more at Highbury; but now their daughter is married I suppose Colonel and Mrs. Campbell will not be able to part with her at all.
column3: I always regret excessively, on dear Emma's account, that she cannot be more at Highbury; but now their daughter is married I suppose Colonel and mrs Campbell will not be able to part with her at all.

column2: She would be such a delightful companion for Emma."
column3: She would be such a delightful companion for Emma."

column2: Mr. Woodhouse agreed to it all, but added:--
column3: mr Woodhouse agreed to it all, but added:--

column2: Our little friend Harriet Smith, however, is just such another pretty kind of young person.	Our little friend Harriet Smith, however, is just such another pretty kind of young person.
column3: true

column2: You will like Harriet.
column3: You will like Harriet.

column2: Emma could not have a better companion than Harriet."
column3: Emma could not have a better companion than Harriet."

column2: I am most happy to hear it; but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be so very accomplished and superior, and exactly Emma's age.
column3: I am most happy to hear it; but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be so very accomplished and superior, and exactly Emma's age.

column2: This topic was discussed very happily, and others succeeded of similar moment, and passed away with similar harmony; but the evening did not close without a little return of agitation.
column3: This topic was discussed very happily, and others succeeded of similar moment, and passed away with similar harmony; but the evening did not close without a little return of agitation.

column2: The gruel came and supplied a great deal to be said--much praise and many comments--undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution, and pretty severe philippies upon the many houses where it was never met with tolerably; but unfortunately, among the failures which the daughter had to instance, the most recent and therefore most prominent was in her own cook at South End, a young woman hired for the time, who never had been able to understand what she meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel, thin, but not too thin.
column3: The gruel came and supplied a great deal to be said-much praise and many comments-undoubting decision of its wholesomeness for every constitution, and pretty severe philippies upon the many houses where it was never met with tolerably; but unfortunately, among the failures which the daughter had to instance, the most recent and therefore most prominent was in her own cook at South End, a young woman hired for the time, who never had been able to understand what she meant by a basin of nice smooth gruel, thin, but not too thin.

column2: Often as she had wished for and ordered it, she had never been able to get anything tolerable.
column3: Often as she had wished for and ordered it, she had never been able to get anything tolerable.

column2: Here was a dangerous opening.
column3: Here was a dangerous opening.

column2: Ah, said Mr. Woodhouse, shaking his head, and fixing his eyes on her with tender concern.
column3: Ah, said mr Woodhouse, shaking his head, and fixing his eyes on her with tender concern.

column2: The ejaculation in Emma's ear expressed, "Ah, there is no end of the sad consequences of your going to South End.
column3: The ejaculation in Emma's ear expressed, "Ah, there is no end of the sad consequences of your going to South End.

column2: It does not bear talking of." And for a little while she hoped he would not talk of it, and that a silent rumination might suffice to restore him to the relish of his own smooth gruel.
column3: It does not bear talking of." And for a little while she hoped he would not talk of it, and that a silent rumination might suffice to restore him to the relish of his own smooth gruel.

column2: After an interval of some minutes, however, he began with--
column3: After an interval of some minutes, however, he began with-

column2: I shall always be very sorry that you went to the sea this autumn, instead of coming here.
column3: I shall always be very sorry that you went to the sea this autumn, instead of coming here.

column2: But why should you be sorry, sir?	But why should you be sorry, sir?
column3: true

column2: I assure you it did the children a great deal of good."
column3: I assure you it did the children a great deal of good."

column2: And moreover, if you must go to the sea, it had better not have been to South End.	And moreover, if you must go to the sea, it had better not have been to South End.
column3: true

column2: South End is an unhealthy place.
column3: South End is an unhealthy place.

column2: Perry was surprised to hear you had fixed upon South End."
column3: Perry was surprised to hear you had fixed upon South End."

column2: I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is quite a mistake, sir.	I know there is such an idea with many people, but indeed it is quite a mistake, sir.
column3: true

column2: We all had our health perfectly well there, never found the least inconvenience from the mud, and Mr. Wingfield says it is entirely a mistake to suppose the place unhealthy; and I am sure he may be depended on, for he thoroughly understands the nature of the air, and his own brother and family have been there repeatedly."
column3: We all had our health perfectly well there, never found the least inconvenience from the mud, and mr Wingfield says it is entirely a mistake to suppose the place unhealthy; and I am sure he may be depended on, for he thoroughly understands the nature of the air, and his own brother and family have been there repeatedly."

column2: You should have gone to Cromer, my dear, if you went anywhere.	You should have gone to Cromer, my dear, if you went anywhere.
column3: true

column2: Perry was a week at Cromer once, and he holds it to be the best of all the sea-bathing places.
column3: Perry was a week at Cromer once, and he holds it to be the best of all the sea bathing places.

column2: A fine open sea, he says, and very pure air.
column3: A fine open sea, he says, and very pure air.

column2: And by what I understand, you might have had lodgings there quite away from the sea--a quarter of a mile off--very comfortable.
column3: And by what I understand, you might have had lodgings there quite away from the sea-a quarter of a mile off-very comfortable.

column2: You should have consulted Perry."
column3: You should have consulted Perry."

column2: But my dear sir, the difference of the journey: only consider how great it would have been.	But my dear sir, the difference of the journey: only consider how great it would have been.
column3: true

column2: A hundred miles, perhaps, instead of forty."
column3: A hundred miles, perhaps, instead of forty."

column2: Ah, my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else should be considered; and if one is to travel, there is not much to choose between forty miles and a hundred.	Ah, my dear, as Perry says, where health is at stake, nothing else should be considered; and if one is to travel, there is not much to choose between forty miles and a hundred.
column3: false

column2: Better not move at all, better stay in London altogether than travel forty miles to get into a worse air.
column3: Better not move at all, better stay in London altogether than travel forty miles to get into a worse air.

column2: This is just what Perry said.
column3: This is just what Perry said.

column2: It seemed to him a very ill-judged measure."
column3: It seemed to him a very ill judged measure."

column2: Emma's attempts to stop her father had been vain; and when he had reached such a point as this, she could not wonder at her brother-in-law's breaking out.
column3: Emma's attempts to stop her father had been vain; and when he had reached such a point as this, she could not wonder at her brother-in-law's breaking out.

column2: Mr. Perry, said he, in a voice of very strong displeasure, "would do as well to keep his opinion till it is asked for.
column3: mr Perry, said he, in a voice of very strong displeasure, "would do as well to keep his opinion till it is asked for.

column2: Why does he make it any business of his to wonder at what I do at my taking my family to one part of the coast or another?
column3: Why does he make it any business of his to wonder at what I do at my taking my family to one part of the coast or another?

column2: I may be allowed, I hope, the use of my judgment as well as Mr. Perry.
column3: I may be allowed, I hope, the use of my judgment as well as mr Perry.

column2: I want his directions no more than his drugs." He paused, and growing cooler in a moment, added, with only sarcastic dryness, "If Mr. Perry can tell me how to convey a wife and five children a distance of a hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense or inconvenience than a distance of forty, I should be as willing to prefer Cromer to South End as he could himself."
column3: I want his directions no more than his drugs." He paused, and growing cooler in a moment, added, with only sarcastic dryness, "If mr Perry can tell me how to convey a wife and five children a distance of a hundred and thirty miles with no greater expense or inconvenience than a distance of forty, I should be as willing to prefer Cromer to South End as he could himself."

column2: True, true, cried Mr. Knightley, with most ready interposition, "very true.
column3: True, true, cried mr Knightley, with most ready interposition, "very true.

column2: That's a consideration, indeed.
column3: That's a consideration, indeed.

column2: But, John, as to what I was telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning it more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows, I cannot conceive any difficulty.
column3: But, john, as to what I was telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning it more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows, I cannot conceive any difficulty.

column2: I should not attempt it, if it were to be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people, but if you call to mind exactly the present light of the path--The only way of proving it, however, will be to turn to our maps.
column3: I should not attempt it, if it were to be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people, but if you call to mind exactly the present light of the path-The only way of proving it, however, will be to turn to our maps.

column2: I shall see you at the Abbey to-morrow morning, I hope, and then we will look them over, and you shall give me your opinion."
column3: I shall see you at the Abbey to morrow morning, I hope, and then we will look them over, and you shall give me your opinion."

column2: Mr. Woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on his friend Perry, to whom he had in fact, though unconsciously, been attributing many of his own feelings and expressions; but the soothing attentions of his daughters gradually removed the present evil, and the immediate alertness of one brother, and better recollections of the other, prevented any renewal of it.
column3: mr Woodhouse was rather agitated by such harsh reflections on his friend Perry, to whom he had in fact, though unconsciously, been attributing many of his own feelings and expressions; but the soothing attentions of his daughters gradually removed the present evil, and the immediate alertness of one brother, and better recollections of the other, prevented any renewal of it.
